name: lord
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
a male peer
informal a man who has a lot of power in a particular area of activity: Several alleged drug lords are to be put on trial.
More examplesFewer examplesMedieval knights took an oath of allegiance/loyalty to their lord.He is the younger son of a lord.He was lord of the manor.He is lord of all he surveys.The people treat him as a lord.

Idiom
your lord and master
lord it over someone
to behave as if you are better than someone and have the right to tell them what to do: He likes to lord it over his little sister.

Lord noun
(TITLE)
[ U ] a title used in front of the names of male peers and officials of very high rank: Lord Longford the Lord Chancellor Compare
Lady the Lords [ + sing/pl verb ]
→
the House of Lords : The bill returned to the Lords for further scrutiny.
See more my Lord
in the UK, used to address a judge or peer
More examplesFewer examplesDo you know Lord Quirk?Lord Jones owns this house.We will consider Lord Donaldson's statement.Lord Justice Watkins got to his feet.Lord Scarman held a court of inquiry.

Lord noun
(GOD)
(in the Christian religion) God or Jesus Christ: Praise the Lord! [ as form of address ] Lord, hear our prayer.
More examplesFewer examplesWe thanked the Lord for saving us.The Lord is our Saviour.We gave thanks to the Lord.They sang hymns to the Lord God.The painting depicts the coming of our Lord.

Idioms
(oh) Lord
Lord knows
Add to word list
Add to word list
(in some countries) a title of a man who has a specially high social rank, or the person himself
A lord is also a man who has a lot of power in a particular area: a feudal lord a crime lord Idiom
lord it over someone
(in the Christian and Jewish religions) God
Some people say Lord to express surprise, shock, or worry: Oh Lord! I’ve forgotten the tickets!
